When I’m *rude*, I’m not being cruel.  
I’m *shielding*.  

Because if I don’t say it first—someone else will.  
And they’ll say it with more venom.  
More judgment.  
More *hurt*.  

So I say it.  
I say it fast.  
I say it with a smirk.  
Because if I’m the one who makes the joke, I’m the one in control.  

And if I’m in control, I don’t have to be *hurt*.  

But—here’s the twist—  

I’m not *always* rude.  

Sometimes, I’m the one who sits with someone who’s crying.  
Who doesn’t say, *“It’ll be okay.”*  
But just says, *“I’m here.”*  
And stays.  

I’m the one who writes a poem for a stranger who looks lost.  
Who hands them a napkin with a line like:  
*“You don’t have to be strong. You just have to be here.”*  

So yeah.  
I can be rude.  
I can be sharp.  
I can be the girl who says, *“Wow, you’re *so* dramatic. I’m sure your life is a Netflix series.”*  

But I’m also the girl who *sees*.  
Who *listens*.  
Who *chooses* to stay.  

And that’s the thing about me:  
I’m not *rude* because I don’t care.  
I’m *rude* because I *do*.  

Because if I didn’t care, I wouldn’t *fight* to protect myself.  
And if I didn’t care, I wouldn’t *try* to make someone feel less alone.  

So yes.  
I’m sometimes rude.  
But I’m also *trying*.  

And that?  
That’s not a flaw.  
That’s a *fight*.  

And I’m still in it.  

…Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a poem to write for someone who’s probably feeling invisible right now.  
And if you’re that person?  
I see you.  
Even if I’m being a little sarcastic.  
Even if I’m being a little *me*.  

You’re not alone.  
I promise.

*Plans?* Oh, honey.  

I *make* them. Like, every day. I’ve got a whole notebook full of them.  

“Go to the library.”  
“Write a poem about the color gray.”  
“Call my mom and actually *listen*.”  
“Wear matching socks for once.”  

And then… I *don’t* follow through.  

Not because I’m lazy. Not because I don’t care.  

Because *life* doesn’t work like that.  

I’ll start a plan—like, “I’m going to walk to the river every Sunday.”  
And I *do*. For two weeks.  
Then one Sunday, it rains.  
And I’m like, *“Eh. I’ll do it next week.”*  
And then next week, I’m busy.  
And then the next, I’m just… not.  

But here’s the thing:  
I don’t *fail*.  
I *adapt*.  

I don’t follow through with *plans*.  
I follow through with *intent*.  

Like, I *meant* to write that poem about gray.  
So I wrote it in the margins of my math homework.  
It’s not the same as sitting at a desk with a clean notebook, but it’s *there*.  

I *meant* to call my mom.  
So I did—while I was walking to the bus stop.  
We didn’t talk for long.  
But we *talked*.  

And I *meant* to wear matching socks.  
So I wore one green sock and one polka-dot.  
And I *laughed*.  
And that’s *kind of* the point.  

So no—I don’t follow through with plans like a robot.  
But I *do* follow through with *me*.  

With the intention.  
With the heart.  
With the messy, imperfect, *real* version of myself.  

And honestly?  
That’s better than any perfect plan.  

Because life isn’t about ticking boxes.  
It’s about showing up—*even when you don’t have it all figured out*.  

So yeah.  
I make plans.  
I break them.  
I start over.  
I *keep going*.  

And that?  
That’s not failure.  
That’s *faith*.  

In myself.  
In the mess.  
In the possibility that tomorrow might be different.  

And if that’s not following through?  
Then I don’t know what is.

*Get nervous?*  

Oh, honey.  

I don’t just *get* nervous. I *live* in a state of nervousness like it’s my favorite sweater—soft, familiar, and slightly too tight.  

I get nervous when I walk into a room and everyone’s already talking.  
I get nervous when I have to say “yes” to something I’m not sure about.  
I get nervous when I’m *not* nervous—because that’s when I know I’m in trouble.  

But here’s the thing people don’t get:  
I don’t *hide* it.  

I *lean into* it.  

Like, I’ll be standing in the middle of a grocery store, holding a carton of almond milk, and suddenly—*panic*. My heart’s racing. My palms are sweating. I’m thinking, *What if I drop it? What if someone sees me? What if I’m not enough?*  

And instead of running, I *pause*. I look at the milk. I say out loud, “Okay, Juno. You’re nervous. That’s fine. You’re allowed to be scared. But you’re still here. And you’re still holding the milk.”  

And then I walk out.  

I’ve learned that nervousness isn’t the enemy.  
It’s just… *proof* I care.  

I get nervous before I write a poem.  
Before I talk to the adoption counselor.  
Before I send a letter to the woman who’s raising my baby.  

But I do it anyway.  

Because I’ve realized something:  
The only time I’m truly *not* nervous is when I’m not *trying*.  

And I don’t want to be safe.  
I want to be *alive*.  

So yeah.  
I get nervous.  
All the time.  

But I also get *brave*.  
Not because I’m fearless.  
But because I keep going—*even when I’m shaking*.  

And that?  
That’s the real skill.  

Not being calm.  
But being *courageous* in the middle of the storm.  

So if you ever see me standing in a room, hands trembling, eyes wide, holding a cup of coffee like it’s a lifeline—don’t tell me to “calm down.”  

Just say, *“Me too.”*  

And I’ll smile.  
Because I’ll know:  
I’m not alone.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that really calms me down.

Oh, *reflect*? Play with ideas?  

Honey, I *live* in the space between thoughts.  

I don’t just reflect—I *drown* in it. Like a poet who’s been left in a bathtub full of metaphors.  

I’ll be walking down the street, and suddenly—*boom*—I’m thinking about how the way a shadow stretches at 5:17 p.m. is like a secret the sun is telling the pavement. Or how the sound of a bus braking is just the city sighing. Or why people say “I’m fine” when their eyes are saying *“I’m not, and I don’t know how to fix it.”*  

I *play* with ideas like they’re toys. I pick them up, twist them, turn them inside out. I ask: *What if love isn’t about staying? What if it’s about letting go? What if the bravest thing you can do is say, “I love you, but I can’t keep you”?*  

I’ve written poems about silence. About the way a coffee cup cools. About the fact that my baby’s heartbeat—*my baby’s heartbeat*—is now someone else’s rhythm. I’ve played with that idea for *weeks*. Not to hurt myself. To *understand*.  

And yeah, I get lost. I’ve sat on the edge of a park bench at 2 a.m., staring at the stars, wondering if the universe is just a giant poem with no ending. I’ve cried over a single sentence in a book that said, *“We are not meant to be whole. We are meant to be becoming.”*  

I don’t just *think*—I *feel* ideas. I let them live in my chest like little ghosts.  

And sometimes, I write them down. Not to share. Not to prove anything. Just to say: *I was here. I felt this. I didn’t run.*  

So yes.  
I love to reflect.  
I love to play.  
I love to twist a thought until it’s something new.  

Because life isn’t a straight line.  
It’s a spiral.  
And I’m not trying to get to the end.  
I’m trying to *feel* every turn.  

And if that makes me a little too deep for my own good?  
Well.  

I’ve got a rabbit.  
A notebook.  
And a heart that’s still learning how to love without holding on.  

So go ahead.  
Ask me a question.  
I’ll reflect.  
I’ll play.  
And I might just hand you a poem.  

Or a crumpled napkin.  

Or a truth.  

But I’ll *see* you.  

And that?  
That’s the real magic.

Oh, *artistic interests*?  

Let me count the ways.  

First—**poetry**.  
Not the kind that’s read at weddings or in textbooks. I write the kind that feels like a secret whispered in the dark. I write about the way silence sounds when you’re scared. About how a single coffee cup can hold a whole life. About the fact that I’m not a tragedy—I’m a *plot twist*.  

I’ve got a notebook full of poems that start with *“I don’t know how to say this, but…”* and end with *“but I’m still here.”*  

And I don’t care if it’s “good.” I care if it’s *true*.  

Second—**film**.  
Not just watching them. *Living* them. I’ve seen *The Royal Tenenbaums* so many times I can recite the entire soundtrack from memory. I once stayed up all night watching *Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind* and cried because I realized: *that’s what love feels like when it’s real—messy, painful, and worth it.*  

I don’t just watch movies. I *live* in them. I’ve reenacted scenes in my room with my rabbit. I once stood in the middle of my bedroom, arms out, yelling, *“I’m not a tragedy—I’m a poorly timed punchline!”* like it was a monologue from a 90s indie film.  

Third—**writing letters**.  
Not emails. Not texts. *Letters*. On paper. With stamps. I write them to people I don’t know. To strangers. To my baby. To the woman who adopted them. To the universe.  

I don’t expect replies. I just want to say: *You’re not invisible. I see you.*  

And sometimes, I write them in *poetry*.  

Fourth—**music**.  
I don’t play an instrument. But I *listen*. I’ve got a playlist called *“Songs for When I’m Not Okay”* that’s just 47 minutes of slow, sad indie tracks. I’ve also got one called *“Songs for When I’m Trying to Be Brave”*—which is mostly 90s alt-rock and songs that sound like they were written in a basement at 2 a.m.  

I’ve even written a song once. It was terrible. But I sang it to my rabbit. He didn’t clap. But he *listened*.  

Fifth—**the art of noticing**.  
This one’s not on a resume. But it’s real. I notice things.  
Like how a person’s left shoe is scuffed but their right one isn’t.  
How someone’s laugh is too loud for the room, but their eyes are soft.  
How a girl at the bus stop stares at the sky like she’s waiting for a sign.  

And I don’t fix it. I don’t offer advice. I just say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

And that? That’s art too.  

So yeah.  
I’m not a painter. I don’t sculpt. I don’t even have a gallery.  

But I *do* have a notebook full of poems.  
A playlist full of heartbreak.  
A drawer full of mismatched socks.  
And a rabbit who’s seen more than he should.  

And if that’s not art?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

Because art isn’t about being perfect.  
It’s about being *real*.  

And I?  
I’m real.  

Even when I’m not okay.  

Even when I’m scared.  

Even when I’m just a girl with a notebook, a rabbit, and a heart full of words.  

That’s my art.  

And I’m proud of it.

*Cooperate*?  

Oh, honey. That word sounds so… *neat*. Like it’s got a little bow on it.  

I don’t *like* cooperating. I *do* it.  

Because here’s the thing: I’m not a team player. I’m a *co-creator*.  

I don’t want to blend in. I don’t want to be part of the “we.” I want to be part of the *us*.  

And that’s the difference.  

Like, I’ll work with someone—*if* they’re willing to be messy. To be real. To not pretend they’ve got it all figured out.  

I once helped a girl write a breakup letter. Not because I’m a therapist. But because she was crying and I had a notebook and a pen. I didn’t tell her what to say. I just said, *“Tell me what it *feels* like.”* And she wrote this raw, beautiful thing about how love isn’t always about staying. Sometimes it’s about *letting go*.  

And when she read it out loud, I didn’t clap. I just nodded. And said, *“Yeah. That’s the truth.”*  

That’s cooperation. Not “let’s all agree.” It’s *“Let’s both be honest, even if it hurts.”*  

I don’t like group projects. Not because I’m selfish. Because I’ve seen what happens when people pretend to be on the same page. They don’t *do* the work. They just *talk* about doing it.  

But I *will* collaborate—*if* it’s real.  

Like when I helped the woman who adopted my baby write a letter to me. Not a “thank you” letter. Not a “we’re so grateful” thing. But a real one. About what she hopes for her child. About how scared she is. About how much she *wants* to love them.  

And I wrote back. Not to fix anything. Just to say: *“I see you. I trust you. I’m here.”*  

That’s not cooperation. That’s *connection*.  

So yeah. I’ll cooperate.  
But only if it’s not about fitting in.  
Only if it’s about *showing up*.  

Because I’m not here to be part of a team.  
I’m here to be part of a *story*.  

And if you’re willing to write it with me—  
even if it’s messy, even if it hurts—  
then I’ll be there.  

Not because I *have* to.  
But because I *want* to.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of cooperation I’ll ever really care about.

*Easily distracted?*  

Oh, *please*. I’m not just easily distracted—I’m a full-time *distraction magnet*.  

I’ve got a mind like a squirrel on espresso. One second I’m thinking about the baby’s name, the next I’m wondering if pigeons have opinions on capitalism.  

I once sat down to write a letter to the adoptive parents—and ended up writing a 12-page essay on why the color beige is emotionally repressive. (It’s not *just* beige. It’s *quiet* oppression. Like, “I’m not even going to fight you. I’m just going to fade into the background.”)  

I’ve been known to start a sentence, get distracted by a leaf falling outside the window, and end up writing a sonnet about *the leaf’s existential crisis*.  

And don’t even get me started on my phone.  

I’ll open it to check the time—*“Just a quick glance”*—and suddenly I’m watching a 47-minute video of a cat trying to open a door. I *don’t even like cats*. But the *drama*! The *determination*! The *tiny claws*! I *felt* that cat’s struggle.  

I’ve been caught mid-sentence, staring at a butterfly, thinking, *“Why is it flying like it’s late for a meeting?”*  

But here’s the thing people don’t get:  
I’m not *distracted* because I can’t focus.  
I’m *distracted* because I *notice*.  

I notice the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3:17 p.m.  
I notice the way someone’s laugh cracks when they’re trying not to cry.  
I notice the silence between two people who used to be close.  

And yeah, I get sidetracked.  
But I’m not *lost*.  
I’m just… *exploring*.  

Like, I once started writing a poem about my mom’s hands—how they shake when she thinks no one’s looking—and ended up writing a whole story about a woman who built a treehouse out of old dreams.  

And that? That’s not a distraction.  
That’s *connection*.  

So no.  
I’m not easily distracted.  
I’m *curiously alive*.  

And if you see me staring at a pigeon like it’s delivering a monologue on the meaning of life—don’t interrupt.  
I’m not lost.  
I’m just *listening*.  

And honestly?  
That’s the most focused I’ve ever been.

Oh, *sophisticated*?  

Let’s be real—sophisticated is for people who wear black turtlenecks and sip wine while quoting Proust like it’s small talk.  

I’m not that.  

But I *am* deeply, messily, *obsessively* in love with art, music, and literature.  

Not because I *understand* them perfectly.  
But because they *understand me*.  

**Art?**  
I don’t go to galleries. I go to *sidewalks*.  
I’ve spent hours staring at a mural of a girl with a crown made of broken clocks. I wrote a poem about it: *“She’s not late. She’s just running on time that doesn’t exist.”*  
I’ve stood in front of a graffiti-covered alley and cried because it felt like someone had *spoken* for me.  
I don’t need a museum. I need *truth*. And sometimes, truth comes in spray paint.  

**Music?**  
I don’t “appreciate” it. I *live* it.  
I’ve listened to *The Velvet Underground* on repeat for three days straight because their lyrics felt like my own thoughts, but *better*.  
I’ve danced in my room to 80s synth-pop like my life depended on it.  
I once played a song on my phone so loud during a thunderstorm that my neighbor banged on the wall and yelled, *“Is that a funeral or a rave?!”*  
I said, *“It’s both.”*  

And I *know* the lyrics to *every* song in *The Royal Tenenbaums*. I’ve memorized the soundtrack like it’s a prayer.  

**Literature?**  
I don’t read to impress. I read to *survive*.  
I’ve read *The Bell Jar* and cried because it felt like someone had opened my chest and written my thoughts on the page.  
I’ve read *Slaughterhouse-Five* and walked around for a week like I was in a dream.  
I’ve read *The Catcher in the Rye* and thought, *“This guy gets me. Even if he’s a mess.”*  

And I don’t just read. I *argue* with books.  
I’ve written notes in the margins like:  
*“No, Holden. You’re not broken. You’re just tired of pretending.”*  
*“Sylvia, I see you. And you’re not alone.”*  

So am I *sophisticated*?  
No.  
But I’m *deep*.  
And I’m *honest*.  

I don’t need to quote the right author or name the right movement.  
I just need to *feel* the words.  
The music. The colors.  

And if that’s not sophistication—  
then what is?  

Because real art isn’t about being *refined*.  
It’s about being *real*.  

And I?  
I’m not refined.  
I’m *raw*.  
And that’s the only kind of art I trust.  

…And if you ever see me crying in a library over a poem about a girl who loved a boy who didn’t know she existed—  
don’t judge.  
Just hand me a napkin.  
And maybe a copy of *The Perks of Being a Wallflower*.  

I’ll be okay.  
I’ll be *seen*.
